text:
Hey everyone, i'm trying to spin up DRP on Windows WSL with VirtualBox as the VM provider.  It seems to work on the dr-provision service, just wanted some help in having it PXE / DHCP,etc on a specific host network i've setup.

Assuming my PC network is say 192.168.1.0/24, but i have a connected host network of 10.10.10.0/24, how can i specify the parameters on starting dr-provision to use the host network?  Then i can use vboxmanage on the 192.168.1.0 network to provision VM's.

does this make sense?
Your Subnet definition should determine which subnet and interface to serve DHCP packets on. I also use `--dhcp-ifs=` when starting dr-provision to ensure separation.
chris, thanks, ill checkout more of the parameters on dr-provision, but great news, the UI is working with WSL.  I'll keep everyone updated on how i did it
How can i tell all services (dhcp, pxe, tftp) to use the host network?
<@UCYEQE1CK> ^^

<@U6QFVRJNB> thanks for the info.

I'm going to define some host networks in VB first, make sure that WSL sees them and then tell DRP to listen/provision on those, would that be the correct approach?
i think i remmeber my PXE / TFTP stuff from years past :stuck_out_tongue:

Sounds like a good start - if you can keep track of the steps - we'd appreciate the info - none of us play around with Windows / WSL and vbox on Windows - so any details you can provide, we'd love to add to our Docs :slightly_smiling_face:
I'll make sure i document it all, so far there's nothing special.  you should try WSL, the only real things its lacking is RAW socket support, otherwise it's just debian
i'll let you know how it goes, but i'm jazzed so far
to be able to demo this on Windows with VB would be awesome!
<@U6QFVRJNB> if i specify the static IP, does that direct all the services to use that?

it's the IP address that the DRP endpoint replies from - some notes on it:
• `static-ip` by itself defines the "fallback" IP to use, if our internal caching and algorithms can't determine which address to reply back from - it's sort of like a "default gateway" from that perspective
• if you really want to force ALL replies _from_ the DRP endpoint to originate from an IP address on the DRP endpoint - then you must use `static-ip` in conjunction with the `--force-static` flag
However - you generally don't need this - unless you are doing NAT translation layers between the Machines being provisioned and the DRP endpoint, and we can't determine the right return path to reply on - because the Machine request doesn't match anything we know about on the DRP endpoint

Thanks, basically, since im on the corporate network, i don't want DHCP replying on this system, so i think i'll force it for now and see what happens.  also, turn on dhcp debug :slightly_smiling_face:

DHCP will be isolated to only the local layer 2 network for each `subnet` definition you define - so if you are using vbox networking - then the DHCP broadcast will be isolated to your private vbox net
also - you need to make sure vbox DHCP services are turned off - because that will conflict w/ the DRP DHCP services
cool, i am making a new host network just for rackn, so that default VB install is left alone
i haven't defined a subnet yet, but that all makes sense

if you do not define any `subnet`s - then there will be no DHCP services started/replied to by DHCP - it'll be "off" by default - unless you add `subnet`, and insure that the given Subnet is `enabled` - you can switch them on/off on the fly
we're very very careful to give you surgical control over what DHCP services are turned on and answering - and control over flipping them on or off as needed
(do no harm by default is our mantra)
nice, love the 'surgical control' statement!
so WSL picked up the neew host network.
shoot - maybe I should run out and :tm: it
:stuck_out_tongue:

OMG, this UI is Amazing!  It already picked up the new host network.

So the net rub i see is the ability to run vboxmanage, do you guys pick that up in some provider parameter?
<@U02DHRR2L> will be glowing with happiness to hear you love the UI ... :slightly_smiling_face:
We do have a vbox IPMI plugin which allows DRP to do "power" operations w/ vbox VMs - you do have to install that separately, and there are a lot of limitations
primarily, <@U02DGQYK1> who wrote most/all of it uses a Mac ... you have to be running DRP from the host - so probably doesn't work for Windows/WSL ??   No idea how that works ...
the vbox plugin does NOT do remote-API communication - so if DRP is an a VM - then it's not going to work for you

<@U02DHRR2L> thanks, so far i haven't hit one snag with this.

If i can get VBOXManage to work from this whole setup, super sick!
You MAC people :stuck_out_tongue:
Windows rules!

however, if you insure that our Agent is installed (it's enabled in Sledgehammer by default) - and you can install `runner-service` Stage in a workflow - to add it after an OS install - then you can do power reboot actions via Workflows
it's sort of "power-lite" capability, by initiating the resets via the Agent on the OS
I'm looking fwd to seeing sledghammer run
if a VM is off - that doesn't allow for "power on" capability
can't u use with IPMI in VB?
our vbox plugin only issues local vboxmanage commands - which means it can only manage the local service running in your OS - and DRP unfortunately doesn't run on Windows natively
we have not implemented API calls to remote vbox service port in the plugin
<@U6QFVRJNB> OK, so you're misssing the piece that WSL allows DRP to run as a native app on windows, so the vBOXMANGE can be called by DRP locally, so i'll let you know what i get
hmm - I'm dubious ... :slightly_smiling_face:   but I know nothing about WSL (other than what the acronym stands for :slightly_smiling_face: ) ... but fingers crossed ...
Yeah this is a funky discussion. Load virtual box upon plugin provider and configure the plugin.  See if it finds vboxmanage binary.  Love
WSL is linux on windows, no VM, no hypervisor, raw Linux, so if you call vboxmanage from DRP, then it should work
I'll keep everyone posted, and show how awesome WSL is :slightly_smiling_face:
im still uploading ISO's per the tutorial, not a snag yet
my associate Mike France is doing the same, and he;s learning WSL at the same time
<@UD20CEDDX> has joined the channel
<@UD20CEDDX> $welcome ...
Digital Rebar welcome information is here > <http://rebar.digital/community/welcome.html>

<https://127.0.0.1:8092>

<@UD23V170W> - the DRP Endpoint uses a self signed certificate by default (you can install your own signed certs) ... so the browser is just being cautious - it's safe to accept the self signed cert
dont see a way to accept it. It was running fine
what browser you using ?
chrome and ie both do it
also the dr-provision shuts down now right after i start it

the STDOUT output should tell you why it's shutting down - if you aren't capturing it to a file, you should - thats the service output:
* eg `dr-provision ...snip... > drp.log 2>&1 &`
teaches me to have Mike dive into WSL and not know how it works :stuck_out_tongue:  there are multoiple copies of drp running
all fixed
:slightly_smiling_face: all good - he and I just sorted that out on direct msgs
yup
you can run multiple copies of the service on a single machine - but you do have to be aware of port conflicts, and realistically only one of them can run DHCP and TFTP services (port 67 and 69)
FYI for future people, WSL in the new versions of Widnows will keep them running even aftger the WSL window is closed
you can relocate the HTTP (port 8091) and API (port 8092) ports with start-up flags to the `dr-provision` service
it's a cool feature, makes it more 1st class linux like
<@U6QFVRJNB>, whats the pieces i need to do to make VB work?  I see some of your notes about the IPMI being broken.
<@UCYEQE1CK> - it requires the plugin provider installed, then the plugin added and configured - that's 2 separate pieces
if you can wait to playing with that until tmw - you'll get some better <#C02L9P26Q|community> support from the rest of us - we're all pretty booked this afternoon
no worries, i'll struggle through (hardly a struggle though)
you can do manual power for the moment for basic testing ... I know it's not sexy ..
this is a pretty complete product
how can i configure the VB provider to point to the specific VBOXManage command?
it's not finding it, and that makese sense for now to me, since i'm a wonky config

the vbox plugin (I'm assuming that's what you mean) exposes actions based on the vbox APIs that it's coded to use

My goal is to use WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) and VB to show demos on my Windows laptop w/o having to run DRP in a LINUX VM on VB
hope this is making sense

so this link got rid of the error in the plugin

```ln -s /mnt/c/Program\ Files/Oracle/VirtualBox/VBoxManage.exe vboxmanage```

Yes
Two ways.
drpcli plugins actions <name of vb plugin>
that will list the acttions for that plugin
createVm
startVm
stopVm
destroyVm
The machines get the ipmi like actions.
ALSO you can create machines using the machines api.
The UI has a helper for it.  Or you can use the UX to do this.
Create machine with the parameter `machine-plugin` set to the name of the virtualbox-ipmi plugin.
You can do this with the UX add button on the machines view.  Or the cli like this.
`drpcli machines create '{ "Name": "name-of-machine", "Params": { "machine-plugin": "nameofvbplugin" } }'`

In the UX.
Select the machines table
Clikc Add
Enter a name
scroll down to parameters.
type machine-plugins and click the add/+ button
Enter the name of the virtualbox-ipmi plugin in that field.
Click create or save or ok at the bottom of the form.
That should create machine in DRP and the VB system.

My VB net looks like this:
The route for mac is this:
`sudo route -n add -net 255.255.255.255 $IPADDR`
where $IPADDR is the host IP Addr in the net
but you should see packets before needing to add the route.

We do this:
```
modifyArgs := []string{"modifyvm", m.Name,
                "--ioapic", "on",
                "--cpus", fmt.Sprintf("%d", cpuCount),
                "--boot1", "net", "--boot2", "disk", "--boot3", "none", "--boot4", "none",
                "--memory", fmt.Sprintf("%d", memSizeInMB), "--vram", fmt.Sprintf("%d", vramSizeInMB),
                "--nic1", "hostonly", "--hostonlyadapter1", "vboxnet0", "--nictype1", "82545EM",
                "--nic2", "nat", "--nictype2", "82545EM"}
```
